token

ã€€During interpretation, scripts are all broken down into units called tokens and processed.
ã€€The boundaries between the token and the next token depend on the type of token.

Naked word

ã€€A "naked word" is a specific sequence of characters written directly in a script that is not quoted ("" or '').
ã€€"Naked words" have the following rules:
ã€€
  • It consists of lowercase and uppercase letters of the alphabet, '_' (under bar), numbers, and so-called full-width characters. However, numbers cannot be at the beginning.
  • Until these sequences end, they are treated as one "naked word"


ä¾‹:
    ampan  // OK
    123a // NG because the number comes first
    _asdf // OK because the underbar can be at the top
    continue // This is a reserved word OK
    å…¨è§’æ–‡å­— // So-called full-width characters are OK as "naked words"

ã€€"Naked words" are further divided into reserved words and identifiers.

Reserved word

ã€€Reserved words are the following, not identifiers. All "naked words" that are not reserved words are identifiers.

break continue const catch class case
debugger default delete do extends export
enum else function finally false for
global getter goto incontextof Infinity
invalidate instanceof isvalid import int in
if NaN null new octet protected property
private public return real synchronized switch
static setter string super typeof throw
this true try void var while with

ã€€Each of these reserved words has a special meaning as an important use in constructing the grammar of a script. Some of these are used as operators.
ã€€However, not all of these reserved words are used in the current version.

identifier

ã€€"Identifier" is any of the "naked words" that are not reserved words. These are used for variables, functions, and class names that can be freely named by the writer.
ã€€If an identifier contains a reserved word but is not a reserved word itself, it will be recognized as an identifier instead of a reserved word.

symbol

ã€€Symbols are also decomposed as tokens. The symbols are as follows.

>>>= >>> >>= >> >= > <<= <=
<-> << < === == => = !== != !
&&= && &= & ||=
|| |= | ... . ++ += + -= -- - *=
* /= / \= \ %= % ^= ^ [ ] ( ) ~
? : , ; { } # $

ã€€These are cut out as tokens with the longest match. For example, ++ is decomposed as ++ instead of + and + . If you want to write them as separate + and +, use a space between + and +. Must be sandwiched.

ã€€Symbols have important meanings as components of the grammar. Some of the symbols are used as operators.

Numeric immediate

ã€€Numeric immediates are numbers or begin with . (decimal point). TJS2 recognizes the following format.
ã€€If you write a number as usual, it will be a decimal number immediate value as it is.

ä¾‹:
    0
    3.1
    342.3
    1

ã€€You can also use e or E for decimal, and specify index with 10 as the base. The meaning is the same for e and E.

ä¾‹:
    1e-3   // 1×10-3
    3.4e10   // 3.4×1010
    9.3E-2  // 9.3×10-2

ã€€If prefixed with 0x or 0X, it will be specified in hexadecimal. The meaning is the same for 0x and 0X.

ä¾‹:
    0x1234
    0Xff
    0x3f33

ã€€If prefixed with 0b or 0B, it will be specified in binary.

ä¾‹:
    0b0100
    0B0010100010100001

ã€€If it is preceded by 0, it is treated as octal.

ä¾‹:
    01234
    033

ã€€For hexadecimal, octal, and binary, exponents can be specified by decimal point format and p. p is a base 2 exponent specification.

ä¾‹:
    0b1.1    // 1 + 1/2 represents 1.5
    0x2.f    // 2 + 15/16 represents 2.9375
    0x1p8    // 1 × 28 represents 256.0


ã€€A numeric immediate is treated as a single numeric immediate as long as it is a constituent character of a numeric immediate.

String immediate

ã€€String immediates (string literals) are enclosed in "" (double quotes) or '' (single quotes). You can use double quotes or single quotes.
ã€€However, ' (single quotation) in "" (double quotation) and " (double quotation) in '' (single quotation) no longer need to be escaped with \.

ä¾‹:
    "this is a string."
    'this is also a string.'
    "Can't use without a quotation."

ã€€\ (backslash) has a special meaning in the string. The meaning changes with the character following the \. The special specification following \ is called escape.


\\    : \ mark itself
\'    : ' (Single quotation)
\"    : " (Double quotation)
\a    : BEL (Audible bell)
\b    : BS (Backspace)
\f    : FF (Form feed)
\n    : LF (Line feed)
\r    : CR (Carriage return)

\t    : HT (Horizontal tab)
\v    : VT (Vertical tab)
\xH   : H=Hexadecimal (H represents the character code)
\XH   : Same as above

ã€€The format is \xH, where H is a hexadecimal number. Then, the hexadecimal number is treated as a character code and replaced by that one character.


ä¾‹:
    'Can\'t help'  (Using \ ')
    "\x1234"     (Character with character code 0x1234 as wide character)

Also, in the format \xH, as long as \x is followed by the characters that make up the hexadecimal number (0-9, A-Z, a-z), it is the H-part. Will be considered. However, up to 4 digits are recognized in a 16-bit wide character environment, and up to 8 digits in a 32-bit machine (16-bit for Windows, 32-bit for Linux and Solaris).
"\x22An Apple" Anyway, the beginning is assumed to be \x22A. To avoid this, write the string separately as "\x22" "An Apple". In TJS, if a string immediate value is continuous like this, it is regarded as one string.

ã€€See also Operations on strings for strings.

String immediate with @

ã€€If you put @ before the string immediate, it will be interpreted as an expression between & and; or between ${ and } in the string immediate, and the result of evaluating it will be expanded there. (If you write an expression between & and ; or between ${ and }, the result will be embedded there.)
ã€€If you don't want to expand & or $, you can prevent & or $ from expanding by placing a \ before & or $.


ä¾‹:
    @"1+2=&1+2;"  (Becomes the string "1 + 2 = 3")
    @"The content of variable f is &f;"  (Expand the contents of variable f to the location of &f;)
    @"The result of calling function func is &func();"  (If valid as an expression, it can be written between & and;)
    @"The result of calling function func is ${func()}"  (Same as above)
    @"true \&\& false is &true && false;"  (& is not expanded if \ is written before &)

ã€€The expression described here can access variables (including local variables) that are accessible from the location where this string is written.

Octet column immediate

ã€€The octet sequence immediate is enclosed by <% and %>, and octet data (binary data) can be written in it.
ã€€For data, specify two or more hexadecimal numbers separated by spaces.

ä¾‹:
    <% 00 01 02 03 %>
    <% ff ff ff 00 04 0f ff 30 %>

ã€€See also Operations on octet columns for octet sequences.

Regular expression pattern

ã€€A regular expression pattern is enclosed between / and /, and you can write a regular expression pattern inside.
ã€€A regular expression pattern can be followed by a flag character, g is a global search flag (match everything found; without this flag only the first one), i is case insensitive The flag, l, is a flag that causes localized collation.
ã€€Regular expression patterns written in this way are treated as objects of the RegExp class.

ä¾‹:
    /[0-9]-[0-9]-[0-9]/
    /^;\s*(.*?)\s*=(.*)$/
    /start(.*?)end/gi

ã€€See also RegExp class for regular expression patterns.
